Author: MikeCapone
Content: Not to mention that the article doesn't actually seem to talk much about science, and spends lots of time talking about authority, despite its claim at the beginning that this should be about science and not authority.

Author: viggity
Content:
And the supporters of global warming are funded by carbon credit companies (Al Gore has stakes in several). Should we not believe them because they too might have an ulterior motive?

Who is funding you is certainly valid question to bring up, but it isn't the end all be all of the argument.

I have a big problem with anyone who says that the science is settled. You don't hear anyone say that the science is settled on the theory of gravity.

In my program, I had to sign a non-disclosure when doing an assignment for a local tech company. They didn't use anything I made, but I can't share it. It's basically gone for a minimum of 4 years.

I always feel like I've lost a little bit of myself when I lose code or IP I've created, even if I'm paid for my time.

Author: mynameishere
Content:
1. The left has sought control of the means of production and distribution from day one.

2. The fight against global warming allegedly requires just that.

3. Follow the money.

It's just a hunch, of course. But any discussion of the problem should focus on three things: 1) Nuclear plants, 2) China, and 3) Proactive solutions. I don't see any of that. The bulk of the solutions offered seem designed to impoverish the developed world.

Author: dlnovell
Content:
God I wish I could down vote this.

Richard Lindzen is quoted in this article. He just happens to have been funded in various ways by ExxonMobile and other companies in big coal and oil for almost two decades. Whenever some nutjob tries to start attacking the "theory" of global warming, they point to him and say "there's an MIT climate scientist who says it's all fake, so clearly there is no consensus". They're never aware that he's being funded by oil companies.

"It is difficult to get a man to understand something when his job depends on not understanding it" - Upton Sinclair

Author: Kirby
Content:
It really does depend on the question. A lot of interview time, particularly on phone screens, is "Does this person's resume reflect reality?" That's where "What's a class?" and "How do you do a join in SQL?" come from, and if the candidate can't easily answer, their resume is bloated, game over. Google it is a bad answer.

Also realize that even though you consider something to be trivia, your interviewer doesn't or the question wouldn't be asked. Saying, "I'd just google it" is dismissive, and people don't like being dismissed.

What you can do is invoke Google techniques as part of a larger problem. Like, "I forget the order of arguments to this function, but that's on Google, can you tell me if I got it right?" When the point of the question isn't the trivia, but the approach.

Author: miloshh
Content:
1. Temperatures are clearly rising.

2. CO2 concentrations are clearly rising.

3. Well-understood physics suggests that rising CO2 should lead to rising temperatures.

Does this make it 100% certain that we're causing global warming? Maybe not, but if you want to disprove the link, you're going to need better arguments than "41% of laypeople think global warming is exaggerated".

Author: nethergoat
Content:
"Today’s incident also shows the fragility of the 'cloud' as it can be knocked out a single lightening strike."

How is this different from any other data center? Note too that on EC2, your instances will be spread randomly throughout the facility - you'd actually be better off having this happen on EC2 vs. in a traditional DC. Furthermore, this was a localized incident inside of a single availability zone - the other four (now five, actually) AZs were completely unaffected.

The author clearly does not know what he is talking about.

I'm glad one commenter on the article had the sense to call him out. Too bad he was followed by the usual set of trolls.

Author: EliAndrewC
Content:
It can definitely be misleading, but it's still a useful metric. When I read "Android barcode scanner in 6 lines of Python code" my thought is, cool, there's clearly a good barcode scanning library for Android in Python and I can look and find easy 6-line examples of how to do something useful with it.

This makes that style of headline much more useful to me than "Python/Android Barcode Scanning Library Example Code" or somesuch, because it gives me some idea of the level of effort required to do something useful with the library (in this case 6 lines).

Author: TrevorJ
Content: The biggest take-away I had from this is that production value, graphics packages and big studio sets aren't what attract people to some content. If the screenshot is any indication most of these videos where poorly lit handheld streams from a single camera. One hopes that if the television industry takes anything away from this it is that people care less about how you dress your show up and more about what the actual content is. If  this had been covered on TV we would have had to sift through commercial breaks, into graphics outro graphics and the incessant jabbering of a couple inane hosts along with the inevitable text crawl at the bottom from viewers texting in (just to show that the network understands social media).

Author: sonofjanoh
Content:
One should sleep whenever he/she's tired.

Anyone who has the luxury to choose what to do with his/her time is extremely successful or at least happy.

And also the quality of sleeping is more important than the quantity. No point sleeping 2 more hours if you feel rested and rejuvenated after only 4-5 hours. And again, lucky is the one who can get to the "office" at 4 AM or 1PM whenever he/she is awake and feel like working...

Author: edw519
Content:
"...this kind of email really angers me..."

Chill.

One of the most important things in business is knowing when and where to expend your energy and passion which, believe it or not, is a limited resource. If this motivates you to change something, great. If it angers you, get a grip and find a better outlet. Anger is a waste. Don't allow them to let you do that to yourself.

Author: TrevorJ
Content: The biggest risk in this is the stick situation you come to when somebody who feels that a legitimate comment was moderated and feels the need to make a fuss about it. It's a little hard to come up with a thoughtful response to that. "Well, my moderators made the decision." "Who are they?" "I don't know them."
